properties.media:imagetext:
CATHAY HOTEL
SHANGHAI
MARCH 2, 1933
Dear Family;
This is my first letter to Dauphin's Island, and I hope that in due course
of time it will reach you there.
There has been no mail from home since Feb. 22 nd
so of course I donot know whether you are going to be South or not.
You can tell the Bacons that the Canadian Pacific Steamship Co. is now
serving "Shrimp a la Seafort Inn" when ever the Empress of Asia can get any real
fresh shrimp.
We had some awfully good shrimp
when we gou to Japan, so 1 asked th
Dining Room steward if he could have some cooked the way we had them at Dauphin
Island. Groeger and I had them
that way,
told some of the other
passengers, and
as a result this dish became very popular.
The steward told me they would
continue
to serve the shrimps that way and
would call the style as I have written it above.
I am still
waiting for certain developments in New York before going ahead
with negotiations here. In the mean time there is plenty to be done in the way of
gathering all sortd of information regarding the principal cities to be served in
case operations are begun, what the facilities are for landing,
type and kind of
surface competition, train and boat schedules, accommodations,
time
in transit,
amount of first class passengers and first class mail moving between certain
polnus,
euc, euc.
Groeger 1s
course helping on all this, and has just returned
from a trip to Peiping (Peking) which he made by boat going
and by air coming b
back so that he could study the water service, harbor facilities, etc. He says
that Peiping is very interesting now with all the excitement.
He met Marshall
Changs pilot who is an old barnstorming flier who used to be in some of Bill Rob-
ertson's air shows at Lambert Field. His name is Perry Hutton. The character of
the old man in The Good Earth is supposed to be the father of Chang,
and
the lat-
ter is Sons. Hutton, another American pilot and two American mechanics are living
the best hotel in Peiping with fat salaries and all expenses paid. Groeger
said they were a very clean wholesome lot of typical American boys who are reap-
ing a harvest out of the necessities of Chang's military "face".
They do not have
much flying to do, and so with the help of a legion of Chineses coolies they keep
the Ford Irimotors looking as though they had just come from the factory.
Last night Col.Jouett called me up and asked me to join a party he
was giving at the Jai Ali.
The Chinese have gone crazy over that game, and they
have some of the best of the Spanish,
mexican and Cuban players come over here.
Col. Jouett's mother,
Mrs.J and Mrs. Christy Matthison were on the party.
